Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

In our district there was custom that obtained for several years that was perhaps peculiar to our district. We were enthusiastic skaters and would go out on the sloughs when they froze in the fall. We have skating parties on sloughs when the season freezing smooth water often didn't occur. And in any case, skating for such parties was restricted as the snow usually came and in sufficient quantities to make skating impossible some winters when the first snowfall was late and no more came for a time although would be kept clear for a period but this was at best an uncertain charity and of uncertain duration.

In these became the skating parties at various times during the winter, possibly once a month or even twice to congregate at one of Grenfell to skate on the covered rink and make up a load and drive into fit on the top of a single sleigh box which supported plants projected over the side of the sleigh box with people facing each other through the length of the box with plenty of room for each other to skate their feet in the box. With plenty of room this was considered the sole of luxury.

Two teams played on a turn were hitched to the sleigh and we would have lunch at a restaurant and return home these evenings were considered the finest word of entertainment. At times the sleigh might upset but this only added to the excitement.

I may say that one family that attended regularly lived about 20 miles from Grenfell so their drive for such nights was quite considerable.

About 1908 it was decided to build a temporary rink of poles and straw in the fall and have a covered rink for the winter. The bottom of a coulee just below a dam was the site chosen as it was very sheltered and water could easily be obtained from the dam for flooding purposes. Since hot water is a necessity in flooding pits for making smooth ice a big iron kettle such as was used in scalding pigs when butchering was set up at the end of the rink and a fire lit under it when the ice was being flooded. A shack was also built on or above the rink and to be used when putting on or taking off skates. Ones living close to the rink alternated in doing the flooding and I may say that this job was always performed meticulously by the ones whose duty it happened to be. No admission was charged and people came from far and wide to skate there and were always welcome. The following fall the buildings were rebuilt and the rink was operated for a second year though after that it was discontinued. The second year our rink was in operation another district, the Hillelden district about seven miles to the south also built a rink on a slough and operated it for one year but one year only.

earlier pioneers were fine people in their own right and were great individualists. It was a pity that so many of them persisted in harboring real or fancied slights or injustices stemming from times gone by. In many cases I venture to say that if asked the reason for their unfriendly feelings they would have been unable to remember the original slight, real or fancied. In this regard I may say that our district was settled by either old Ontario people, many of whom had knowledge of each other before coming West, or people born and bred in the British Isles. Perhaps if the district had been settled by a more mixed people old prejudices would not have had the same prominence. Our district was entirely Protestant, largely of Methodist persuasion who were very strict in their ideas and such people often find it hard to make allowance for others who do not share their beliefs regarding the right and wrong of many things.

In this regard in answer to Question II re what card games were played in the homes in our district it was commonly accepted that standards playing cards were not allowed at any time or under any circumstances. Authors was the recognized popular and proper game for years with Finnish later becoming popular. Games which were modeled after common card games even were frowned upon such as "Lost Heir," "Old Maid" was regarded as a little on the childish side but admissible. Checkers among the men was very popular of course and a good checker player was not without honor in any company. I must say that those families who indulged in the regular card games were always most considerate of the feelings of the families who didn't so indulge and I cannot remember a single instance of the belliers being made to feel uncomfortable because of their belliers.

Among the Methodists dancing was absolutely taboo and it was many years before a dance was ever held in our school at home, and then it wasn't put on as a dance but was railroaded in by some fellows living on the edge of the district proper following a Christmas party. I was about twelve years old at the time and I can well remember the hard feelings resulting and that lasted for many years. Of course many districts didn't have the same code of behaviour and school dances were the order of the day in the winter months. But the Methodist sect was very prevalent in those days and at many schoolhouses were never held.

13 - The Chivaree was a popular institution at those times and I can remember taking part in several. It was reared as a little of a good reputation but a couple who were married during a busy season could hardly expect their neighbors to drop important work to organize a Chivaree in their honor. Sometimes of course they were mischievous and stood and were resented especially if some participant became over-enthusiastic but were usually received in the best of spirits and the participants invited in for a lunch.
